column4: in trying to use qemu, i now try to use the cdrom to start the installation of the "guest", and i get this error : "you do not have enough space in '/dev/shm/ for the 256 mb of qemu virtual ram.  to have more space available provdided you have enough RAM and swap, do as root : umount /dev/shm"
i did just that, and  it said that '/dev/shm' was "busy"
you can't unmount /dev/shm
so how do i take care of this "256 mb" problem ?
that means you don't have enough memory for the new VM
can i do this : "mount -t tmpfs -o size=272m none /dev/shm" while "/dev/shm" is running ?
/dev/shm represents shared memory http://is.gd/zMN6
how do i determine how much memory i have on my linux box
i am certain it is at least 512..but how do i confirm
free -m
or check in the system monitor
total       used       free     shared    buffers     cached
-/+ buffers/cache:        378        115
http://paste.ubuntu.com/172266/
means you have around 494MB memory in total
that's usually not enough memory to use in a desktop OS plus a 256MB VM
so what about "swap" why do it said used : 1443
thanks
that is you have about 1443 MB is swap space in total. Swap is something similar to virtual memory in Windows
